item.title: 'Genie is not a game engine:' Take-Two president says Google's world model cannot replace creative process
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 4, 2026

3 Min Read

Last week, Google unleashed Project Genie upon the world. The generative AI tool is described a "general-purpose world model" capable otherwise of creating interactive environments. 

The prototype web application is powered by Genie 3, Nano Banana Pro and Gemini. It can, in the words of Google, be used to sketch, explore, and remix "living" virtual worlds that have been produced via text or impact prompts. 

Almost immediately, some people used Genie to churn out (legally-dubious) facsimiles of video game such as The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and Super Mario 64 (via The Verge). One person seemingly used it to create a dodgy imitation of Grand Theft Auto set in Greenland while proclaiming the end of video game studios is nigh (thanks, LadBible). 

As reported by Reuters, it seems some investors shared that belief, with video game stocks sliding across the board after Google rolled out the tech. 

Related:Take-Two Interactive delivers 'outstanding' quarter after GTA beats forecasts

Yet, when asked about the technology during a recent earnings call, Take-Two president Karl Slatoff stressed that tools like Genie cannot and should not be compared to traditional video game engines. 

"Genie is early in its iteration at this point and trying to make a comparison to a game engine is just really–they're not even in the same ballpark. Genie is not a game engine," he added. 

"[...] I think there will be a moment in time where that will become more defined. It certainly doesn't replace the creative process. And I would say, look, I mean, it looks to me more like a procedurally generated interactive video at this point. There are limitations and Google has said as much. So to compare the technologies, I think there's really no way to do that because they're so far apart."

"There are so many more elements to game development that go beyond world creation"

Even without accounting for the fact that Genie's virtual worlds crumble into digital sludge in seconds, Slatoff stressed what some people are evidently forgetting: there is more to a video game than a character gliding through an ramshackle environment cobbled together by tool that is only capable of replication as opposed to creation. 

"There are so many more elements to game development that go beyond world creation. And the question is what is the world creation? So even beyond world creation, there's everything else that's involved," continued Slatoff. 

"There's the storyline, there's emotional connection, there's vibe, there's mission structure. All of those things you cannot capture through AI and certainly not through a world builder. So that's just a very, very small component of what we do. And if this tool bears out, it will make a component of what we do all that much better and more efficient." 

Related:Epic Games announces Fortnite collab program to bolster store sales

Take-Two itself has been vocal about its support of generative AI tools, with CEO Strauss Zelnick explaining the company is "actively embracing" the technology to "drive efficiencies" and "reduce costs." 

That isn't changing any time soon. 

Speaking to investors during the company's latest earnings call, Zelnick said he hopes that generative AI will one day become a creative force. 

"Just a reminder, our strategy has three parts: be the most creative, be the most innovative and be the most efficient company in the entertainment business. And generative AI squarely falls within the category of innovation and is already moving into the category of efficiency," said Zelnick.

 "I'm hopeful that it will also move into the category of creativity as it allows our creators to use digital tools to expand what we do to make it even more beautiful and even more engaging and even more exciting."

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton. 



https://www.gamedeveloper.com/business/-genie-is-not-a-game-engine-take-two-president-says-google-s-world-model-cannot-replace-creative-process

item.title: Take-Two Interactive delivers 'outstanding' quarter after GTA beats forecasts
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 4, 2026

2 Min Read

Grand Theft Auto maker Take-Two Interactive recorded net bookings of $1.76 billion during what it described as an "outstanding" third quarter. 

According to the company's fiscal report for third-quarter ended December 31, 2025, net bookings from recurrent consumer spending also increased by 23 percent year-on-year and accounted for 76 percent of total net bookings. 

Due to that momentum, Take-Two has raised its guidance and now expects net bookings to range from $6.65 billion to $6.7 billion by the end of the current fiscal year. 

"At the midpoint, our revised Net Bookings forecast is approximately $725 million above the initial outlook we provided in May 2025, which reflects the creative passion, hard work, and consistent execution of our teams," reads the fiscal report.

Grand Theft Auto V sold another 5 million units during Q3 and has now sold-in over 225 million copies worldwide. 

Take-Two CEO Strauss Zelnick said the franchise continues to vastly outpace internal forecasts, with recurrent consumer spending associated with GTA increasing by 27 percent during Q3. That upswing was driven by GTA Online's latest update, A Safehouse in the Hills, which reintroduced GTA V protagonist Michael De Santa.

Related:Epic Games announces Fortnite collab program to bolster store sales

Zelnick added that GTA+, a membership program launched exclusively for GTA Online, continues to "thrive" and explained subscriber numbers have doubled year-over-year. He reiterated that GTA VI will launch on November 19, 2026, following multiple delays and unrest at developer Rockstar. 

As for Rockstar's other major release, Red Dead Redemption 2 has now sold-in over 82 million units globally. 

Take-Two continues to benefit from Zynga acquisition

Zelnick also praised the performance of Take-Two's mobile business and major sports franchises. He noted that Toon Blast—a mobile title developed by Zynga-owned studio Peak—grew by 43 percent year-on-year and crossed $3 billion in lifetime net bookings. 

"The game continues to rank among our most valuable franchises, showcasing the long-term value of our match-three portfolio," he added. The long-serving chief exec also lauded Zynga titles Empires and Puzzles and Words with Friends—which grew by 11 percent and 6 percent, respectively. 

In the world of sports sims, he said NBA 2K26 delivered a "stellar quarter" and has now sold roughly 8 million units worldwide. That milestone represents a high single-digit percentage increase over NBA 2K25. 

NBA 2K is now on track to deliver the highest level of annual net bookings and recurrent consumer spending in franchise history. 

Related:Xbox veteran Larry Hryb joins consulting agency Fractional after Unity layoff

"Our execution throughout Fiscal 2026 has been extraordinary and we are highly confident as we approach Fiscal 2027—which promises to be groundbreaking for Take-Two and the entire entertainment industry–led by the November 19 release of Grand Theft Auto VI with Rockstar’s launch marketing set to begin this Summer," added Zelnick. 

"With ongoing momentum in our business, coupled with our robust forward release schedule, we continue to project record levels of Net Bookings in Fiscal 2027, which we believe will establish a higher financial baseline, set us on a path to enhanced profitability, and provide further balance sheet strength and flexibility."

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.
